prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3 continuum: Dark GRB 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to observe a gamma-ray burst in TargetOfOpportunity mode at band 3. Note that no source coordinates have been defined in Field Setup. This setup is for the first GRB.

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note: The first observation should be performed as soon as possible within the constraints of the observatory (ALMA's reaction time of two weeks will not compromise our science goal).
The first observation should be performed as soon as possible within the constraints of the observatory (ALMA's reaction time of two weeks will not compromise our science goal).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This proposal is aimed at detecting the continuum emission of GRB afterglows in two bands to determine the flux density and the spectral slope at several epochs. The data will be combined with observations at other wavelengths (see Sect. 2 in the main text) to produce detailed models. We choose band 3 for being the most weather independent. The second band would optimally be band 7 as it gives a wider wavelength span and can also trace better the host galaxy star-formation rate in the late observations of the host galaxy.
>Sensitivity:
Our science goals foresee an rms of 31 mu-Jy in band 3 (97.5 GHz). Our estimates indicates that with this sensitivity we should be able to detect ca. 75% of the GRB afterglows (see Fig. 2). The scaling of the sensitivity has assumed a spectral slope of 1/3, expected for a synchrotron spectrum between the self-absorption and the injection frequency, which gives, from the OT Sensitivity Calculator, an estimated total on-source integration time of 12 minutes.
The total time, including overheads, for meeting the science goals for each trigger is 40 min. Since we propose to trigger two times, we are asking for a total time of 1.34 hours in band 3 for one GRB.
>Imaging:
GRB afterglows are seen as point-like sources, so no constraint is imposed in spatial resolution, and hence any array configuration is suitable. The scheduling blocks that can be generated from the science goals in the OT can be executed in any configuration.
>Correlator setup:
We will use correlator in TDM mode with 4 basebands of 2 GHz bandwidth each. Since the usable bandwidth for each baseband is 1.875 GHz, this will give us a total frequency coverage of 7.5 GHz.
>Calibration:
No special calibration is needed.
>Bandpass accuracy
The aim of the proposal is to recover the continuum emission.
>Scheduling/time constraints:
This is a target of opportunity program. We ask to obtain two epochs for each object. The first observation will be performed as soon as possible within the constraints of the observatory. ALMA’s reaction time of two weeks will not compromise our science goal. The second observation would be between one and two weeks (depending on the conditions and scheduling constraints at the telescope) after the first, allowing us to determine the evolution of the afterglow and detect possible changes in the spectral slope. The first/second visit should we scheduled close to the observation in B7 (GRB 1).
>Data rate:
N/A
>Special constraints on standard observing modes:
This is a ToO program. The proposed flux limits ensure a recovery rate of ~75%. Unfortunately, this results in unavoidable significant overheads. However, this is the most efficient way to observe these unique extragalactic objects.

This proposal is aimed at detecting the continuum emission of GRB afterglows in two bands to determine the flux density and the spectral slope at several epochs. >Imaging:

>Correlator setup:
We will use correlator in TDM mode with 4 basebands of 2 GHz bandwidth each. Since the usable bandwidth for each baseband is 1.875 GHz, this will give us a total frequency coverage of 7.5 GHz.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3 continuum: Dark GRB Host 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to observe a gamma-ray burst in TargetOfOpportunity mode at band 3. Note that no source coordinates have been defined in Field Setup. This setup is for the host of the first GRB.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This proposal is aimed at detecting the continuum emission of GRB afterglows in two bands to determine the flux density and the spectral slope at several epochs. The data will be combined with observations at other wavelengths (see Sect. 2 in the main text) to produce detailed models. We choose band 3 for being the most weather independent. The second band would optimally be band 7 as it gives a wider wavelength span and can also trace better the host galaxy star-formation rate in the late observations of the host galaxy.
>Sensitivity:
Our science goals foresee an rms of 31 mu-Jy in band 3 (97.5 GHz). Our estimates indicates that with this sensitivity we should be able to detect ca. 75% of the GRB afterglows (see Fig. 2). The scaling of the sensitivity has assumed a spectral slope of 1/3, expected for a synchrotron spectrum between the self-absorption and the injection frequency, which gives, from the OT Sensitivity Calculator, an estimated total on-source integration time of 12 minutes.
The total time, including overheads, for meeting the science goals is 40 min.
>Imaging:
GRB hosts are only slightly extended. We put a limit of 0.4'' on the spatial resolution. This is a good trade off between detecting the host galaxy and also resolving it.
>Correlator setup:
We will use correlator in TDM mode with 4 basebands of 2 GHz bandwidth each. Since the usable bandwidth for each baseband is 1.875 GHz, this will give us a total frequency coverage of 7.5 GHz.
>Calibration:
No special calibration is needed.
>Bandpass accuracy
The aim of the proposal is to recover the continuum emission.
>Scheduling/time constraints:
This is the host observation to target 1. There is no special scheduling constraint.
>Data rate:
N/A
>Special constraints on standard observing modes:
This is a ToO program. The proposed flux limits ensure a recovery rate of ~75%. Unfortunately, this results in unavoidable significant overheads. However, this is the most efficient way to observe these unique extragalactic objects.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Long gamma-ray burst (GRB) are the brightest explosions in the Universe, having been already detected between redshifts of 0.008 and 9.4. About 25-40% of all GRB afterglows evade detection in the optical despite deep limits. This optical darkness can be explained in most cases by extinction (44%) and for a small number by a high redshift (z>7, 5%). However, the knowledge of their emission mechanisms and their environments is rudimentary. To obtain a better understanding, we propose to exploit the outstanding sensitivity of ALMA to observe the continuum emission of the afterglow of two GRBs in bands 3 and 7 at 3 epochs for each GRB with three main goals:
i) Precise localisation of the afterglow to within <1.1'',
ii) Modelling of the radio-to-X-ray afterglow to determine the emission mechanisms, and the physical parameters of the GRB and its environment, and
iii) Assessing the unobscurred star-formation rate and mapping out star-formation in the host galaxy.
In total, we request 9.4 hours of observing time. We will trigger only on bursts for which we can guarantee an accompanying multi-wavelength follow-up.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
